message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation of high blood pressure in the upper extremity, weak femoral pulses, and a systolic murmur with a systolic ejection click over the left sternal border and back are all suggestive of coarctation of the aorta. Takayasu arteritis involves inflammation of large arteries and would present with other symptoms such as headache, dizziness, and visual changes. Interrupted aortic arch would present with severe cyanosis and a harsh systolic ejection murmur. Pheochromocytoma is a tumor that produces excessive amounts of catecholamines and would be less likely to present with high blood pressure in only one extremity.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical exam findings suggest coarctation of the aorta. Interrupted aortic arch would present with absent femoral pulses. Takayasu arteritis presents with absent or diminished pulses in the upper extremities. Pheochromocytoma would not cause hypertension in just one extremity.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The combination of high blood pressure in one arm, weak pulses in the legs, and a systolic murmur with a systolic ejection click over the left sternal border and back is most indicative of coarctation of the aorta. Takayasu arteritis is a rare disease that can cause narrowing and inflammation of large blood vessels, while Interrupted aortic arch is associated with cyanosis and heart failure. Pheochromocytoma can cause hypertension, but it would not explain the other findings in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The elevated blood pressure in the right upper extremity and weak femoral pulses suggest coarctation of the aorta. Interrupted aortic arch is unlikely given the normal heart sounds and normal point of maximal impact. Takayasu arteritis usually presents in young females and the symptoms are not consistent with pheochromocytoma.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has a significant difference in blood pressure between the upper extremities, which is a classic sign of coarctation of the aorta. The systolic murmur and systolic ejection click are also common findings in coarctation of the aorta. Takayasu arteritis usually presents in young women and has various symptoms such as weight loss and fever. Interrupted aortic arch usually presents in neonates with severe cyanosis. Pheochromocytoma does not cause findings of unequal blood pressures between the upper extremities.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has a high blood pressure in the right upper extremity but decreased pulses in the lower extremities, which is consistent with coarctation of the aorta. The systolic murmur at the left sternal border and back is also a common finding with this condition. The other options do not fit the presentation of the patient.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The elevated blood pressure in the right upper extremity and the presence of a systolic murmur with systolic ejection click over the left sternal border suggests a diagnosis of coarctation of the aorta. The absence of other symptoms or findings makes other options less likely.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest coarctation of the aorta, which can result in hypertension in the upper extremities, reduced or absent pulse in the lower extremities, and a systolic ejection murmur. The other options do not fit with the patient’s presentation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The elevated blood pressure in the right upper extremity and weak femoral pulses suggest a possible coarctation of the aorta. The presence of a systolic ejection click over the left sternal border and back suggests an associated bicuspid aortic valve.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The elevated blood pressure in the right upper extremity with 2+ radial pulses and trace femoral pulses is suggestive of coarctation of the aorta. The 2/6 long systolic murmur with systolic ejection click heard over the left sternal border and back also supports this diagnosis. Takayasu arteritis can cause blood pressure abnormalities, but typically affects the aorta and its branches bilaterally. Interrupted aortic arch usually presents with severe hypotension and shock in the neonatal period. Pheochromocytoma usually presents with hypertension, but not with the characteristic finding of coarctation of the aorta.
